page.title: 09Kennet and Avon Canal.
page.content: In 1720 the idea of trying to link the{River Avon}to the{River Thames}was first suggested. The mill owners of the{Kennet Valley}objected as they needed the free flowing water of the river for their mills.However, in 1723 the first section of the navigation was built, connecting{Reading}to {Newbury. The{River Avon}was navigable to {Bristol,}but in 1724 the 11 miles from {Bristol}to{Bath}were canalised.This was the section from Hanham Mills to the famous Pultney Weir. There were six locks built to deal with the 30 foot rise from Bristol.This section was built at very little cost as there was no tow path and the barges were bow hauled by the bargees. In 1793, John Rennie, an engineer was asked to survey a canal to link ]
